moves.1. d4: I like it when white opens with d4, as it creates an opportunity to play the Dutch. In this battle black will advance on the king side and sacrifice a pawn and a rook in the final combination.
A king side fianchetto is usually recommended for white. But this is also a pretty normal response for white.
moves.6... O-O 7. Be2 Qe8: The fashionable Qe8 version of Leningrad Dutch.
moves.8. O-O c6: Trying to discorage Nb5, with the threat of Nc7 forking the queen and the knight.
moves.9. Qb3: Seen a lot on gameknot. Supposed to be an unusual but playable move.
moves.9... Kh8: White threatens a discovered check after c5.
moves.10. d5: This is a very normal move as well. It should probably not be used together with the Qb3.
moves.10... Na6 11. Ng5: The placement of the knight on g5 and the bishop on f4 will be a big help for black when he starts to advance his king side pawns.
moves.11... Nc5: The knight homes in on its best sqaure, and threatens the queen at the same time. The queen blocks a b4 pawn advance that could chase the knight.
moves.13. Qe1 Bd7 14. Bd1 h6: Starting the pawn advance. Winning one tempo because white must move the knight.
moves.15. Nf3 g5: Winning another tempo as white must move the bishop.
moves.16. Bg3 e5: The bishop on g3 is almost locked in. Preparing f4.
moves.17. h3: Creating an escape square for the bishop. White could have trid dxe6.
moves.17... g4: Sees the opportunity to open the h file for the queen.
moves.18. hxg4: As the knight is threatened, white cannot avoid a pawn exchange opening the g or h file.
moves.18... Nxg4: Having the knight influence the h2 square, which is a potential mating square for the queen. fxg4 looked like a good option as well.
moves.19... Qh5: Protecting the f5 pawn as well as binding white pieces to the defence of h2.
moves.20. Nh4: Locking the queen out, and again attacking the f5 pawn.
moves.20... e4: Avoids the return of the knight to f3 and protects the f5 pawn from the c2 bishop. Also limits that bishops range.
moves.21... Be5: Attacking both the g3 bishop, and the h4 knight which is protected by it.
moves.22. Bxg4: Exchanging to get rid of the mating threat on h2.
moves.22... Qxg4: Queen must retake or be taken.
moves.23... Bf6: Attacking the h4 knight, which is now underprotected.
moves.24. Bxd6: Grabbing a pawn and forking the knight and the rook.
moves.24... Qxh4: The computer revealed Nd3, moving the knight out of danger and threatening the white queen.
moves.25. Bxc5: Better than grabbing the rook. Now white is a pawn up.
moves.25... Rfg8: Moving the rook to safety and intensifying the attack against the king.
moves.26. Ng3: Protecting the g2 pawn pawn against the rook and attacking the e4 and f5 pawns.
moves.26... Be5: Controlling an important diagonal. If white gains control of this, the knight on g3 will be hard to get rid of.
moves.27. Bd4: Pins the bishop to the king.
moves.27... Bxd4: The exchange opens up the advance of the f pawn. Better than the alternative Rae8.
moves.28. exd4 f4: Sacrificing the pawn on e4 to get the knight out of the way.
moves.29... Rxg2+: Sacrificing the rook to get rid of the g2 pawn.
moves.30. Kxg2 Qh3+: Getting the king away from its escape exit at f3.
moves.31. Kg1 f3: White resigned. White have no moves to avoid Qg2#
